question: A person 'X' hits another person 'Y' with a wooden stick on provocation. This leads to formation of a bruise 3cm x 3cm on the forearm. No other injuries are noted. Which of the following is true, regarding his punishment:
exp: C i.e. Imprisonment for 1 month and/or fine of Rs. 500/- - Emasculation (class 1), permanent privation of sight of either eye (2), or hearing of either ear (3) privation of any pa (member) or joint (4) destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint (5) permanent disfiguration of head or face (6) fracture / dislocation of bone or tooth (7) and any hu which endangers life or which causes sufferer to be, during the period of 20 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his/ her ordinary pursuits (class 8) are included in grevious hu (section 320 IPC). - To be counted as grevious hu, the loss of privation of sight or hearing may be paial and need not be complete but has to be permanent. Again permanent does not mean that it should be incurableQ. For example, when loss of sight is due to corneal opacity due to some injury, it is curable by corneoplasty. But as because corneal opacity is permanent by itself it will be considered grevious huQ & chances of cure by corneoplasty does not minimize its gravity-Apurba Nandy 2/e P-203. Abrasion heals completely without leaving any disfiguration or deformity of hence its a simple injuryQ. Contusion of scalp does not produce permanent disfiguration as it reves to normal in few weeks. - Contrary to popular belief, a simple stay in hospital for 20 days or deliberately delaying the healing of simple hu by patient for 20 days do not constitute grevious injury. And a stay of < 20 days (even with bodily pain) is not considered a grevious injury. Grevious hu is a cognizable offence for which a police officer can arrest a person without a warrant from magistrateQ. Punishment for voluntarily causing simple (non grevious) hu on provocation with simple (non dangerous) weapon is imprisonment extending upto 1 month and/or fine upto Rs. 500/- or bothQ. Stick is a non dangerous weapon and bruise on forearm is simple (not grevious) huQ.
opa: Imprisonment for one year and/or fine of Rs. 1000
opb: Imprisonment for two years and/or fine of Rs. 5000
opc: Imprisonment for 1 month and/or fine of Rs. 500

question: Which is not a feature of cocaine poisoning: September 2011
exp: Ans. C: Hypothermia Cocaine when ingested results in hypehermia, hallucinations, euphoria and stimulation of libido Cocaine intoxication With excessive or prolonged use, the drug can cause itching, tachcardia, hallucinations and paranoid delusions. Overdoses cause tachyarrythmias and a marked elevation of blood pressure, which can be life-threatening. Toxicity results in seizures, followed by respiratory and circulatory depression of medullar origin. This may lead to death from respiratory failure, stroke, or hea-failure. Cocaine is also highly pyrogenic, because the stimulation and increased muscular activity cause greater heat production. Heat loss is inhibited by the intense vasoconstriction. Cocaine-induced hypehermia may cause muscle cell destruction and myoglobinuria resulting in renal failure. Emergency treatment often consists of administering a benzodiazepine sedation agent, such as diazepam to decrease the elevated hea rate and blood pressure. Physical cooling (ice, cold blankets, etc.) and paracetamol (acetaminophen) may be used to treat hypehermia There is no officially approved specific antodote for cocaine overdose Cocaine's primary acute effect on brain chemistry is to raise the amount of dopamine and serotonin in the nucleus accumbens (the pleasure center in the brain); this effect ceases, due to metabolism of cocaine to inactive compounds and paicularly due to the depletion of the transmitter resources (tachyplaxis). This can be experienced acutely as feelings of depression, as a "crash" after the initial high.

question: Miner's cramp are due to ?
exp: Ans. is 'b' i.e., Heat cramps Exposure to high atmospheric temperatures causes three clinical conditions :? 1. Heat cramps/Miner's cramps/Stoker's cramp/Firemen's cramp These are painful spasm of voluntary muscles which follow sternous work in a hot atmosphere. These are caused by loss of water and salt in profuse prespiration (sweating). 2. Heat exhaustion/heat collapse/heat syncope/heat prostration There is collapse without any elevation of body tempetature. It occurs due to exposure to high temperature in closed environment and is precipitated by muscular exercise and unsuitable clothing. There is extreme exhaustion with peripheral vascular collapse with scanty prespiration (sweating). 3. Heat stroke (heat hyperpyrexia/sunstroke) it is due to failure of heat regulating mechanism caused by failure of cutaneous circulation and sweating. It occurs due to exposure to heat in open and humid environment. There is sudden collapse with loss of consciousness. Skin is dry, hot flushes and there is no sweating. All signs of shock are present, i.e. low urine out put, low BP, rapid irregular pulse etc.
